body:
cross validation is performed with f1_score binary for binary average for binary, and macro for multi-class and multi-label. MAE for continuous but we are working on our own metric "distribution of absolute error" so that might become the default. But you have to be on >=v.0.4.7. 

You might find the docstring regarding this (in v.0.4.7) useful. 

```
        '''Evaluate a model based on f1_score (all except regression)
        or mae (for regression). Supports 'binary', 'multi_class',
        'multi_label', and 'regression' evaluation.
        x : array
            The input data for making predictions
        y : array
            The ground truth for x
        model_id : int
            It's possible to evaluate a specific model based on ID. Can be None.
        folds : int
            Number of folds to use for cross-validation
        sort_metric : string
            A column name referring to the metric that was used in the scan_object
            as a performance metric. This is used for sorting the results to pick 
            for evaluation.
        shuffle : bool
            Data is shuffled before evaluation.
        mode : string
            'binary', 'multi_class', 'multi_label', or 'regression'.
        asc : bool
            False if the metric is to be optimized upwards (e.g. accuracy or f1_score)
        print_out : bool
            Print out the results. 
```
Take a look at the [source code](https://github.com/autonomio/talos/blob/daily-dev/talos/commands/evaluate.py) as well.
To add here that the next step for evaluation is the ability to input custom evaluation metrics or at least to choose from any of the sklearn ones.

Sorry I did not explain well, which metrics is uses here for evaluation:
```
scan = ta.Scan(X_train, y_train,
                params=params,
                dataset_name=dataset.name,
                x_val=X_test,  #WICH METRIC IS USED HERE???
                y_val=y_test,  #WICH METRIC IS USED HERE???
                experiment_no=date,
                model=dataset.getCNNModel,
                grid_downsample=1)
```
if k-cross-fold validation is performed wich is the value of k?

Scan(...) does not involve cross-validation directly. x_val and y_val are treated with whichever metric you choose in your Keras model. So anything that Keras support and you set. Then  when you pick best model later, you will use that model to pick the best model, and only then cross-validation is performed.

So the results reported in csv file like val_loss, val_acc, val_recall_acc.... are performed on x_val and y_val right? it's not correct here to pass the test set as I write in the previous answer, the test set have to be used after picking up the best model, then perform evaluation on that model with k-cross-validation am I wrong?
```
scan = ta.Scan(X_train, y_train,
                params=params,
                dataset_name=dataset.name,
                x_val=x_val,  #HERE VALIDATION SET AND NOT TEST SET
                y_val=y_val,  #HERE VALIDATION SET AND NOT TEST SET
                experiment_no=date,
                model=dataset.getCNNModel,
                grid_downsample=1)
```

then evaluation on test set:
```
    e = ta.Evaluate(scan)
    
    # perform the evaluation
    e.evaluate( x_test, y_test,
                model_id=None,
                folds=10,
                shuffle=True,
                metric='val_acc',
                mode = 'bynary',
                asc=False, #set to true for loss
                print_out=False)    

```

A good practice (when data size permits) is to first split the data into 2 parts of equal sizes. The first part becomes the input data for Scan(...) and you could handle that either implicitly using validation split or explicitly by feeding that data in. The second part goes later to evaluation. This is the best practice.

i've got little dataset so I decide to split in 60% training, 20% validation and 20% testing. Maybe is not the perfect size, but with small dataset my model need data to train . Reasonably I think this is a quite god choice. When I try to evaluate with a different metric than 'val_acc' for example 'val_loss' as below
```
e.evaluate( X_test, y_test,
                model_id=None,
                folds=10,
                shuffle=True,
                metric='val_loss',
                #mode = 'bynary',
                asc=True) #set to true for loss
                #print_out=False)    
```

i get :  59.81% (+/- 14.81%)

1. why I get  a percentage?

2. what (+/- 14.81%) means?

3. if I try to specify mode or print_out I get :TypeError: evaluate() got an unexpected keyword argument 'mode', maybe because I haven't the last version of talos??? talos version: '0.4.3'

1) it's the % of correct predictions i.e. your models is right 60% of the time
2) it means the standard deviation of the folds i.e. your cross-validation folds have std of 14.81%
3) yes you have to get on with the latest version:

First or good measure: 
`pip uninstall talos`

Then: 
`pip install git+http://github.com/autonomio/talos@dev`

OR

`pip install git+http://github.com/autonomio/talos@daily-dev` (I personally always use this)

rename.to: how to evaluate model/s from scan_object?

body:
I am using the functional api where I have 2 inputs. When trying to use evaluate: e.evaluate([X_test_1, X_test_2], y_test.values, folds=10, mode='binary') I am getting this error. Any suggestions?
/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/talos/commands/evaluate.py in evaluate(self, x, y, model_id, folds, shuffle, metric, mode, asc, print_out)
     65         model = activate_model(self.scan_object, model_id)
     66 
---> 67         kx, ky = kfold(x, y, folds, shuffle)
     68 
     69         for i in range(folds):

/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/talos/utils/validation_split.py in kfold(x, y, folds, shuffled)
     66 
     67     if shuffled is True:
---> 68         x, y = shuffle(x, y)
     69 
     70     out_x = []

/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/wrangle/shuffle.py in shuffle(x, y)
      9     random.shuffle(random_index)
     10 
---> 11     x = x[random_index]
     12     y = y[random_index]
     13 

TypeError: only integer scalar arrays can be converted to a scalar index

issue.title: How do I pass in a list of inputs?

repository.name: talos
repository.description: Hyperparameter Optimization for TensorFlow, Keras and PyTorch

issue.body:
In most talos code examples, X input seems to be a 2D numpy array.
But in some of my keras models, it requires a list of 2D numpy arrays because my models are not `Sequential`.
Example list: `[numpyarray1, numpyarray2, numpyarray3]`.

It seems that when I try to pass this list to the `ta.Scan` function, things break.

How do I pass in a list of inputs?

Also, I'm not sure if `talos` supports `pandas` DataFrame or not. But I think it does not support so please do make support for it.
